title: How to Make a Hockey Puck Rain Gauge

steps.headline: Obtain materials:
Obtain access to tools:
Find the centre of the hockey puck:
Insert the spade bit into the drill press.
Set the drill press speed low.
steps.description: Hockey pucks are soft. Using a slow speed prevents melting of the edge of the hole.

steps.headline: Adjust the drill press depth of plunge, so the spade bit will leave about ⁄4 to ⁄8 inch (0.6 to 1.0 cm) undrilled material at the bottom of the hole.
steps.description: You do not want to drill all the way through the hockey puck.

steps.headline: Use clamps, a drill press vise, or other mechanism to hold the hockey puck securely on the drill press table, with the centre of the hockey puck exactly positioned under the point of the spade bit.
Drill the hole in the puck.
steps.description: Do not go all the way through.

steps.headline: Clean up the puck and erase any pencil lines.
Test by inserting the rain gauge base into the hole.
steps.description: It should be loose enough that it can be removed for reading small amounts of rain, and for emptying. But it should be tight enough that it will stay upright and not be blown out by a gust of wind.

steps.headline: Remove the rain gauge from the hockey puck, and run a brass flat-head screw through the centre of the hole.
steps.description: That screw is used for anchoring the hockey puck to a board (deck railing, for instance). When snugged down, the screw should not interfere with the rain gauge.

steps.headline: You're done!
steps.description: Install the rain gauge outside, and hope for a rainy day to come soon.

text:
Obtain materials: Hockey puck. Cost about 20c, or package of 10 for $2.00{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-1Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-1Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-1Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-1Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Obtain access to tools: Drill press. An inexpensive press is just fine for this project. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Spade bit, same size as base of the rain gauge. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Find the centre of the hockey puck: Estimate the location of the centre and make a small mark. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Measure the distance from the mark to the edges of the puck. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Move the mark until all distances to the edge are the same. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} If drawing lines on the puck, keep them in the central area so they will disappear when the hole is drilled in the puck. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet4.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet4.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Hockey-Puck-Rain-Gauge-Step-3Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Insert the spade bit into the drill press. Set the drill press speed low. Hockey pucks are soft. Using a slow speed prevents melting of the edge of the hole. Adjust the drill press depth of plunge, so the spade bit will leave about ⁄4 to ⁄8 inch (0.6 to 1.0 cm) undrilled material at the bottom of the hole. You do not want to drill all the way through the hockey puck. Use clamps, a drill press vise, or other mechanism to hold the hockey puck securely on the drill press table, with the centre of the hockey puck exactly positioned under the point of the spade bit. Drill the hole in the puck. Do not go all the way through. Clean up the puck and erase any pencil lines. Test by inserting the rain gauge base into the hole. It should be loose enough that it can be removed for reading small amounts of rain, and for emptying. But it should be tight enough that it will stay upright and not be blown out by a gust of wind. Remove the rain gauge from the hockey puck, and run a brass flat-head screw through the centre of the hole. That screw is used for anchoring the hockey puck to a board (deck railing, for instance). When snugged down, the screw should not interfere with the rain gauge. You're done! Install the rain gauge outside, and hope for a rainy day to come soon.
